questions.question: What is the Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratio and why does it matter for weight?
options: A ratio of gut bacteria; higher Firmicutes is linked to more efficient calorie extraction and obesity
questions.explanation: The F/B ratio refers to the relative abundance of Firmicutes versus Bacteroidetes bacteria. Obese individuals often have higher Firmicutes ratios. Firmicutes are more efficient at extracting calories from food.

questions.question: What is metabolic endotoxemia?
options: Chronic low levels of bacterial LPS in the bloodstream from leaky gut, causing inflammation and insulin resistance
questions.explanation: Metabolic endotoxemia refers to chronic low levels of LPS (lipopolysaccharides) in the bloodstream due to leaky gut. Even small amounts of LPS trigger inflammation and promote insulin resistance, contributing to metabolic syndrome.

questions.question: What foods increase Akkermansia muciniphila?
options: Polyphenol-rich foods like cranberries, pomegranate, and green tea
questions.explanation: Polyphenol-rich foods promote Akkermansia growth: cranberries, pomegranate, grape seed extract, and green tea. Prebiotic fibers like inulin also help. Intermittent fasting and moderate exercise support growth as well.

questions.question: How long does it take to break the sugar craving cycle by changing diet?
questions.explanation: Breaking the sugar craving cycle typically requires 2-4 weeks of sugar restriction. During this time, sugar-loving bacteria and Candida decrease while beneficial bacteria increase. Die-off can cause temporary increased cravings before improvement.

questions.question: What percentage of T4 to T3 thyroid hormone conversion happens in the gut?
questions.explanation: About 20% of T4 to T3 conversion happens in the gut. This means gut health directly affects how much active thyroid hormone is available, regardless of what the thyroid gland produces.

questions.question: How many criteria are needed to diagnose metabolic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Metabolic syndrome requires 3 of 5 criteria: 1) High waist circumference, 2) Elevated triglycerides (≥150), 3) Low HDL, 4) High blood pressure (≥130/85), 5) Elevated fasting glucose (≥100).

questions.question: Why is berberine useful for metabolic health?
options: It improves blood sugar similar to metformin AND addresses gut dysbiosis
It's a stimulant for weight loss
questions.explanation: Berberine has dual benefits: it improves blood sugar control comparable to metformin AND it's an antimicrobial that addresses gut dysbiosis. It also increases Akkermansia, reduces inflammation, and may help with weight loss.

questions.question: Why do 95% of diets fail long-term?
options: The microbiome adapts slowly (3-6 months) and can push back to old patterns
Exercise is more important than diet
questions.explanation: The body defends its set point through metabolic adaptations. The microbiome adapts slowly and 'remembers' previous patterns, pushing you back. Sustainable change requires changing the microbiome itself, which takes 3-6 months.

questions.question: Why is the Hashimoto's-gluten connection important?
options: Gliadin (gluten protein) structurally resembles thyroid tissue, causing molecular mimicry
Gluten is the only treatment for Hashimoto's
questions.explanation: Gliadin (a protein in gluten) structurally resembles thyroid tissue. Through molecular mimicry, the immune system may attack both. Hashimoto's and celiac frequently co-occur, and gluten-free diets reduce thyroid antibodies in many patients.

questions.question: What is the recommended sustainable rate of weight loss?
questions.explanation: Sustainable weight loss is 1-2 lbs per week maximum. This allows the microbiome time to adapt and helps prevent the metabolic adaptations that cause weight regain. Faster weight loss typically leads to faster regain.
